{{short description|Anti-LGBTQ+ rhetoric}} {{See also|LGBT rights opposition}} [[Image:Seattle gay parade-protesters.jpg|thumb|Anti-LGBT demonstration in [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], United States]] {{LGBT sidebar}} '''Anti-LGBTQ+ rhetoric''' are themes, [[catchphrase]]s, and [[slogan]]s that have been used against [[homosexuality]] or other [[non-heterosexual]] [[sexual orientation]]s in order to demean [[lesbian]], [[gay]], [[bisexual]], and [[transgender]] ([[LGBT]]) people. They range from the demeaning and the pejorative to expressions of hostility towards [[homosexuality and religion|homosexuality which are based on religious]], medical, or moral grounds. It is a form of [[hate speech]]<ref name="FRA">{{cite web | url=https://fra.europa.eu/sites/default/files/fra_uploads/1226-Factsheet-homophobia-hate-speech-crime_EN.pdf | title=Hate Speech and Hate Crimes against LGBT Persons | publisher=European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights | date=2009 | access-date=20 June 2019}}</ref><ref name="ILGA-Europe">{{cite web | url=https://ilga-europe.org/what-we-do/our-advocacy-work/hate-crime-hate-speech | title=Hate crime & hate speech | publisher=ILGA-Europe | access-date=20 June 2019}}</ref> which is illegal in countries such as the Netherlands, Norway, and Sweden.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dn.se/nyheter/sverige/lag-om-hets-mot-folkgrupp-innefattar-homosexuella|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120724173853/http://www.dn.se/nyheter/sverige/lag-om-hets-mot-folkgrupp-innefattar-homosexuella|title=Lag om hets mot folkgrupp innefattar homosexuella - DN.SE|date=24 July 2012|archive-date=24 July 2012|newspaper=Dagens Nyheter|access-date=20 June 2019|last1=Morén|first1=Kristoffer}}</ref>
Anti-LGBTQ+ rhetoric often consists of [[moral panic]] and/or [[conspiracy theory]]. In Eastern Europe, these conspiracy theories are based on earlier [[antisemitic conspiracy theories]] and posit that the LGBT movement is an instrument of foreign control and domination.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Herdt |first1=Gilbert |title=Moral Panics, Sex Panics: Fear and the Fight Over Sexual Rights |date=June 2009 |publisher=NYU Press |isbn=978-0-8147-3723-1 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Klosowska |first1=Anna |editor1-last=Sierra |editor1-first=M. |editor2-last=Román-Odio |editor2-first=C. |title=Transnational Borderlands in Women's Global Networks: The Making of Cultural Resistance |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-0-230-11947-5 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vatfAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT185 |language=en |chapter=Trouble in the Global Village: A Snapshot of LGBT Community in Eastern Europe|date=6 June 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Sherry |first1=Michael S. |title=Gay Artists in Modern American Culture: An Imagined Conspiracy |date=2007 |publisher=University of North Carolina Press |isbn=978-0-8078-8589-5 |language=en}}</ref>
==Anti-gay rhetoric== Anti-gay activists claim that homosexuality goes against traditional [[family values]], or that homosexuality is a [[Trojan Horse]], or that it "destroys families" and humankind<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/ahead-of-olympics-russia-raises-anti-lgbt-rhetoric-1.1562570 |title=Russia raises anti-LGBT rhetoric at home while softening message to West | CTV News |publisher=Ctvnews.ca |date=2013-11-27 |access-date=2014-03-12}}</ref> through [[homosexual recruitment]] which will lead to the extinction of humanity.
===Causing disasters=== The argument that homosexuals cause [[natural disasters]] has been around for more than a thousand years, even before [[Justinian]] blamed earthquakes on "unchecked homosexual behavior" in the sixth century.<ref name="encyclopedia">{{cite book |last1=Dynes |first1=Wayne R. |title=Encyclopedia of Homosexuality: Volume II |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-36812-0 |page=870 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g7TOCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT120 |chapter=Myths & Fabrications|date=22 March 2016 }}</ref> This trope was common in [[early modern]] Christian literature;<ref>{{cite book |last1=Greenberg |first1=David F. |title=The Construction of Homosexuality |date=15 August 1990 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |isbn=978-0-226-30628-5 |page=168 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RKhFRgR-1awC&pg=PA168 |language=en}}</ref> homosexuals were blamed for earthquakes, floods, famines, plagues, invasions of [[Saracens]], and field mice. This discourse was revived by [[Anita Bryant]] in 1976 when she blamed homosexuals for droughts in California.<ref name="encyclopedia" /> In the US, right-wing religious groups including the [[Westboro Baptist Church]] continue to claim that homosexuals are responsible for disasters.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Dominey-Howes |first1=Dale |last2=Gorman-Murray |first2=Andrew |last3=McKinnon |first3=Scott |title=Queering disasters: on the need to account for LGBTI experiences in natural disaster contexts |journal=Gender, Place & Culture |date=2014 |volume=21 |issue=7 |pages=905–918 |doi=10.1080/0966369X.2013.802673|s2cid=146478126 |url=https://ses.library.usyd.edu.au/handle/2123/21638 }}</ref> Homosexuals have been blamed for hurricanes, including [[Hurricane Isaac|Isaac]], [[Hurricane Katrina |Katrina]], and [[Hurricane Sandy|Sandy]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dowling |first1=Tim |title=Superstorm Sandy and many more disasters that have been blamed on the gay community |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/shortcuts/2012/oct/30/hurricane-sandy-disasters-blamed-gay-community |access-date=24 August 2020 |work=The Guardian |date=30 October 2012}}</ref> In 2020, various religious figures including Israeli rabbi [[Meir Mazuz]] have argued that the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] is divine retribution for same-sex activity or [[pride parades]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Religious figures blame LGBT+ people for coronavirus |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-lgbt/religious-figures-blame-lgbt-people-for-coronavirus-idUSKBN20W2HL |access-date=24 August 2020 |work=Reuters |date=9 March 2020 |language=en}}</ref>
Reverend [[Jerry Falwell]] blamed homosexuals (among others) for indirectly causing the [[September 2001 attacks]] by provoking the aggression of [[Islamic fundamentalism|Islamic fundamentalists]] and causing God to withdraw his protection for America. On the broadcast of the Christian television program ''[[The 700 Club]]'', Falwell said, "You helped this happen." He later clarified that "I would never blame any human being except the terrorists".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2001/US/09/14/Falwell.apology/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130330131939/http://archives.cnn.com/2001/US/09/14/Falwell.apology/ |archive-date=March 30, 2013 |title=CNN report of Falwell's speech |publisher=Archives.cnn.com |access-date=2014-03-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Falwell and Robertson Blame Liberal America |url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/falwell-and-above/ |access-date=24 August 2020 |work=Snopes.com}}</ref>
In 2012, Chilean politician {{ill|Ignacio Urrutia|es}} claimed that allowing homosexuals to serve in the [[Chilean military]] would cause Perú and Bolivia to invade and destroy his country.<ref>{{cite news |title='Si aceptan homosexuales en el Ejército, Perú y Bolivia nos volarán la raja' {{!}} Noticias {{!}} elmundo.es |url=https://www.elmundo.es/america/2012/10/10/noticias/1349900629.html |access-date=5 September 2020 |work=www.elmundo.es |date=2012}}</ref>
===={{anchor|AIDS}}Causing AIDS==== {{Further|AIDS#Stigma|Gay-related immune deficiency}} An outgrowth of the discourse on homosexuality causing disasters argues that [[HIV/AIDS]] is divine punishment for homosexuality.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Bright |first1=G. |title=Plague-Making and the AIDS Epidemic: A Story of Discrimination |date=14 February 2012 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-1-137-01122-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vcRfAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT198 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="encyclopedia" /><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Murphy |first1=T F |title=Is AIDS a just punishment? |journal=Journal of Medical Ethics |date=1988 |volume=14 |issue=3 |pages=154–160 |doi=10.1136/jme.14.3.154|pmid=3184138 |pmc=1375741 |doi-access=free }}</ref> During the early years of the AIDS epidemic in the 1980s, mainstream newspapers labeled it a "gay plague".<ref>{{cite news |title='Gay plague': The vile, horrific and inhumane way the media reported the AIDS crisis |url=https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2018/11/30/world-aids-day-1980s-headlines-tabloids/ |access-date=21 August 2020 |work=PinkNews |date=30 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Dowsett |first1=Gary |editor1-last=Herdt |editor1-first=Gilbert |title=Moral Panics, Sex Panics: Fear and the Fight over Sexual Rights |date=2009 |publisher=NYU Press |isbn=978-0-8147-3732-3 |pages=130– |language=en |chapter=The "gay plague" revisited: AIDS and its enduring moral panic}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Howard |first1=Ken |last2=Yamey |first2=Gavin |title=Magazine's HIV claim rekindles "gay plague" row |journal=BMJ : British Medical Journal |date=2003 |volume=326 |issue=7386 |pages=454 |doi=10.1136/bmj.326.7386.454 |pmc=1125344 |issn=0959-8138}}</ref> For a few years the misleading technical name for the disease was [[gay-related immune deficiency]].<ref>{{cite news |title=The terrifying experiences of a gay man who lived through the AIDs crisis |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/love-sex/aids-crisis-1980-eighties-remember-gay-man-hiv-positive-funerals-partners-disease-michael-penn-a7511671.html |access-date=21 August 2020 |work=The Independent |date=6 January 2017 |language=en}}</ref>
The slogan "AIDS Kills Fags Dead" appeared during the early years of AIDS in the United States, when the disease was mainly diagnosed among male homosexuals and was almost invariably fatal. The slogan caught on quickly as a catchy [[truism]], a [[chant]], or simply something written as [[graffiti]]. It is reported that the slogan first appeared in public in the early 1990s, when [[Sebastian Bach]], the former lead singer of the [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band [[Skid Row (American band)|Skid Row]], wore it on a [[t-shirt]] thrown to him by an audience member.<ref>Michael Musto. "La Dolce Musto", village voice, 2000. {{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/nyclife/0022,musto,15284,15.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2007-03-26 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070322195624/http://www.villagevoice.com/nyclife/0022%2Cmusto%2C15284%2C15.html |archive-date=2007-03-22 }}</ref> The slogan "AIDS cures fags" is used by the Westboro Baptist Church.<ref>{{cite news |title=Anti-Gay Protesters Descend on LISD |url=https://www.kcbd.com/story/1597495/anti-gay-protesters-descend-on-lisd/ |access-date=21 August 2020 |work=kcbd.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Claussen |first1=Dane S. |title=Sex, Religion, Media |year=2002 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |isbn=978-0-7425-1558-1 |page=193 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IldQ0C0mTxIC&pg=PA193 |language=en}}</ref>
===Homosexual agenda=== {{Main|Homosexual agenda}}
The derogatory term "homosexual agenda" is applied to efforts to change government policies and laws on [[lesbian]], [[gay]], [[bisexual]], and [[transgender]] ([[LGBT]]) issues, for example, [[same-sex marriage]] and [[civil unions]], [[LGBT adoption]], recognizing [[Suspect classification|sexual orientation as a protected civil rights minority classification]], [[Sexual orientation and military service|LGBT military participation]], inclusion of [[LGBT history]] and themes in [[public education]], introduction of [[anti-bullying legislation]] to protect LGBT minors—as well as non-governmental campaigns and individual actions that increase visibility and cultural acceptance of LGBT people, relationships, and identities. The term has also been used by some [[social conservatism in the United States|social conservatives]] to describe alleged goals of [[LGBT rights]] activists, such as supposed [[homosexual recruitment|recruitment]] of heterosexuals into a "homosexual lifestyle".<ref name="ref-cluster">[http://thinkprogress.org/lgbt/2012/07/09/512916/hate-group-homosexual-activists-try-to-confuse-children-to-build-their-numbers/ Hate Group: 'Homosexual Activists' Try To 'Confuse Children' To 'Build Their Numbers'] ''[[Think Progress]]'' July 9, 2012. *[https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2012/01/a-peek-at-conservatisms-anti-gay-conspiracy-theorist-fringe/250959/ A Peek at Conservatism's Anti-Gay Conspiracy Theorist Fringe] *[https://www.advocate.com/year-review/2014/12/23/years-craziest-right-wing-conspiracy-theories-about-lgbt-people This Year's Craziest Right-wing Conspiracy Theories about Gay People] *[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/15/us/ugandan-gay-rights-group-sues-scott-lively-an-american-evangelist.html Ugandan Gay Rights Group Sues U.S. Evangelist] *[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/22/bryan-fischer-gay-rights-abortion-environmentalism_n_1619128.html Bryan Fischer Slams Gay Rights, Abortion And Environmentalism As 'The Work Of Satan Himself'] *[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/06/caiden-cowger-teen-radio-host-gay-obama_n_1574524.html Caiden Cowger, Conservative Teen Radio Host, Slams President Obama For "Making Kids Gay"] *[http://www.metroweekly.com/2010/01/anti-gay-maryland-legislator-e/ Anti-gay Maryland legislator, Emmett Burns, moves again to cut off recognition of out-of-state gay marriages] *</ref>
In the [[United States]], the phrase "the gay agenda" was popularized by a video series produced by the evangelical religious group, Springs of Life Ministries in California, and distributed by many [[Christian Right]] organizations, the first video of which was called ''The Gay Agenda'' and was released in 1992.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Herman|first=Didi|title=The Anti-Gay Agenda: Orthodox Vision and the Christian Right|publisher=University of Chicago Press|date= 1998 <!-- (ebook, 2007) -->|isbn=9780226327693|ref={{harvid|Herman|1998}} }}</ref>{{rp|81-81}} In the same year the [[Oregon Citizens Alliance]] (a conservative Christian political activist organization) used this video as part of their campaign for [[Oregon Ballot Measure 9 (1992)|Ballot Measure 9]] to amend the Oregon Constitution to prevent what the OCA called [[special rights]] for gays, [[lesbian]]s, and [[bisexual]]s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Signorile|first=Michelangelo|year=1993|title=Queer In America}}</ref>
[[Paul Cameron]]—co-founder of the Institute for the Scientific Investigation of Sexuality in Lincoln, later renamed the [[Family Research Institute]]—appeared in the video, wherein he asserted that 75 percent of gay men regularly ingest [[feces]] and that 70–78 percent have had a [[sexually transmitted disease]].<ref>{{harv|Herman|1998|p=78}}</ref> ''The Gay Agenda'' was followed by three other video publications; ''The Gay Agenda in Public Education'' (1993), ''The Gay Agenda: March on Washington'' (1993) and a feature follow-up ''Stonewall: 25 Years of Deception'' (1994). The videos contained interviews with [[LGBT rights opposition|opponents of LGBT rights]], and the series was made available through [[Christian right]] organizations.<ref>{{harv|Herman|1998|pp=80–81}}</ref>
{{unordered list |In 2003, [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] Justice [[Antonin Scalia]] wrote in his dissent in the landmark case ''[[Lawrence v. Texas]]'' that
{{quote|Today's opinion is the product of a Court, which is the product of a law-profession culture, that has largely signed on to the so-called homosexual agenda, by which I mean the agenda promoted by some homosexual activists directed at eliminating the moral opprobrium that has traditionally attached to homosexual conduct.<ref>{{harv|Cobb|2006|p=161}}</ref>}}
|In 2004, [[Oklahoma]] Senator [[Tom Coburn]] rated the "gay agenda" as a more pressing danger than any [[terrorist]] activity affecting Americans.<ref name=Moulitsas>{{cite news |title=Kissing the tarantula: US blogger Markos Moulitsas marvels at the Tories' attempts to woo the gay vote, in stark contrast to the stance of US conservatives |last=Moulitsas |first=Markos |date=May 5, 2005 |newspaper=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2005/may/05/election2005.comment1 |quote=To the newly elected Republican senator from Oklahoma, Tom Coburn, the "gay agenda" is a more pressing danger than terrorists flying planes into buildings and killing allied troops in Iraq. "The gay community has infiltrated the very centres of power in every area across this country, and they wield extreme power ... That agenda is the greatest threat to our freedom that we face today," he said during the 2004 campaign. "Why do you think we see the rationalisation for abortion and multiple sexual partners? That's a gay agenda." }}</ref>
|In 2019 two prominent [[Roman Catholic]] cardinals - [[Raymond Leo Burke]] and [[Walter Brandmuller]] wrote an open letter to [[Pope Francis]] calling for an end of "the plague of the homosexual agenda" which they blamed for the sexual abuse crisis engulfing the Catholic Church. They claimed the agenda was spread by "organized networks" protected by a "conspiracy of silence".<ref>https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-47302817</ref>}}
==== Responses ==== [[File:Militant Gay Atheist Hugs Rally to Restore Sanity.jpg|thumb|upright|A man satirizing the concept of a gay agenda at the [[Rally to Restore Sanity and/or Fear]]]] The [[Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation]] (GLAAD) describes the term as a "rhetorical invention of [[Homophobia|anti-gay]] extremists seeking to create a climate of fear by portraying the pursuit of civil rights for LGBT people as sinister".<ref name=glaad_terms>{{cite web|url=http://www.glaad.org/reference/offensive|title=GLAAD Media Reference Guide: Offensive Terms to Avoid|publisher=GLAAD}}</ref> Such campaigns based on a presumed "gay agenda" have been described as [[anti-gay propaganda]] by researchers and critics.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Duberman |first=Martin B. |year=1997 |title=A queer world: the Center for Lesbian and Gay Studies reader |publisher=NYU Press |isbn=978-0-8147-1875-9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ksbz9vEpzxIC }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last1=Mason |first1=Gail |year=1997 |title=Homophobic violence |first2=Stephen |last2=Tomsen |publisher=Hawkins Press |isbn=978-1-876067-04-5 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JS_t92NOMF8C }}</ref>
A [[satire|satirical]] article by Michael Swift which appeared in the ''[[Gay Community News (Boston)|Gay Community News]]'' in February 1987 entitled "Gay Revolutionary" describes a scenario in which homosexual men dominate [[American society]] and suppress all things heterosexual. This was reprinted in ''[[Congressional Record]]'' without the opening line: "This essay is an outré, madness, a tragic, cruel fantasy, an eruption of inner rage, on how the oppressed desperately dream of being the oppressor."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/pwh/swift1.html|title=Fordham University: Michael Swift – Gay Revolutionary (the complete essay)|access-date=10 May 2017}}</ref>
====Ugandan bill====
Uganda borrowed from the anti-gay rhetoric and influence of the [[Christian right|American religious right]] to influence public opinion, and eventually persuade parliament to pass the [[Uganda Anti-Homosexuality Act, 2014|Uganda Anti-Homosexuality Act]] (previously called the "Kill the Gays bill").
In 2009, a workshop entitled "Seminar on Exposing the Homosexuals' Agenda" was held in Kampala, Uganda organized by the {{as written|reason=Do not link; this is a Uganda organization, not the [[Family Life Network]] in New York State|Family Life Network}}, and led by Ugandan [[Stephen Langa]].<ref name="kaoma-2010">Kaoma, Kapya (Winter 09/Spring 10). [http://www.publiceye.org/magazine/v24n4/us-christian-right-attack-on-gays-in-africa.html The US Christian Right and the Attack on Gays in Africa], PublicEye.org. Accessed 26 August 2020.</ref> The workshop featured three American evangelial Christians: [[Scott Lively]], author of several books opposing homosexuality; [[Caleb Lee Brundidge]], an [[ex-gay]] man who conducts sessions to heal homosexuality; and [[Don Schmierer]], a board member of [[Exodus International]], an organization devoted to promoting "freedom from homosexuality through the power of Jesus Christ".<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20101226032522/http://www.exodusinternational.org/content/category/6/24/57/ About us], Exodus International (2005). Retrieved 7 January 2009.</ref><ref>[http://www.exgaywatch.com/wp/2009/03/open-letter-to-the-exodus-international-board-of-directors/ ''exgaywatch.com''], 2009/03.</ref> The theme of the conference was the "[[gay agenda]]": the threat posed to Bible-based values and traditional American family. They discussed [[conversion therapy]], how gay men often sodomized teenage boys and how "the gay movement is an evil institution" whose goal is "to defeat the marriage-based society and replace it with a culture of sexual promiscuity".<ref name="gettleman-2010">Gettleman, Jeffrey (3 January 2010). [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/04/world/africa/04uganda.html Americans’ Role Seen in Uganda Anti-Gay Push], ''The New York Times''. Accessed 26 August 2020.</ref> According to Ugandan Kappy Kaoma who was in attendance, "[The parliament] feels it is necessary to draft a new law that deals comprehensively with the issue of homosexuality and ...takes into account the international gay agenda. ... Right now there is a proposal that a new law be drafted."<ref name="kaoma-2010" />
Within a month, the Anti-Homosexuality Bill of 2009 was introduced in Parliament with penalties up to capital punishment. That did not succeed, but by 2013 Parliament passed a law which was then signed into law by President Museveni with penalties up to life imprisonment for "the offense of homosexuality".<ref name="Uganda-Act-2014">[https://www.refworld.org/pdfid/530c4bc64.pdf Text of the Anti-Homosexuality Act, 2014 as signed into law]</ref>
===Homosexuality as unnatural=== [[File:Park Kosynierow in Poznan (chlopak dziewczyna normalna rodzina).jpg|thumb|Graffiti in [[Poznań]]: "Boy–girl is the normal family"]] Describing homosexuality as unnatural dates back to [[Plato]], [[Aristotle]], and [[Thomas Aquinas]]. However, there is no single definition of "unnatural". Some of those who argue that homosexuality is unnatural in the sense of being absent from nature, an argument refuted by the presence of [[homosexuality in animals]]. Others mean that the genitals were created for reproduction (either by God or natural selection) and are not intended to be used for purposes they deem "[[unnatural sex|unnatural]]". Proponents of this idea often argue that homosexuality is immoral because it is unnatural, but opponents argue that this argument is [[is–ought problem|is–ought conflation]]. Some proponents of the "unnaturalness" thesis argue that homosexual behavior is the result of "[[homosexual recruitment|recruitment]]" or willful sinfulness. However, if the [[causes of sexual orientation]] (still a matter of scientific debate) are [[biology and sexual orientation|biological]], this undermines their argument to an extent.<ref name=Hopkins>{{cite book |last1=Hopkins |first1=Patrick D. |title=Queer Philosophy |publisher=Brill {{!}} Rodopi |isbn=978-94-012-0835-2 |pages=1–9 |doi=10.1163/9789401208352_002 |chapter=Naturalizing homosexuality: biology, sexual orientation, and the nature/culture distinction|year=2012 }}</ref>
====As a disease==== Some of those who called homosexuality unnatural, such as [[Traditional Values Coalition]] head and [[Christian right]] activist [[Louis Sheldon]], said that if it were proven to be a biologically based phenomenon, it would still be diseased.<ref name="Hopkins" /> The psychiatric establishment once [[Homosexuality and psychology|medicalized same-sex desire]]. In the United States, homosexuality was removed in 1973 as a [[mental disorder]] from the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]] (DSM) as it did not meet the criteria for a mental disorder.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Drescher|first=Jack|date=2015-12-04|title=Out of DSM: Depathologizing Homosexuality|journal=Behavioral Sciences|volume=5|issue=4|pages=565–575|doi=10.3390/bs5040565|issn=2076-328X|pmc=4695779|pmid=26690228}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soulforce.org/article/642|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100324080417/http://www.soulforce.org/article/642|url-status=dead|archive-date=24 March 2010|title=Gay Is Okay With APA (American Psychiatric Association)|date=24 March 2010}}</ref><ref name="amici">{{cite web|url = http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/Amer_Psychological_Assn_Amicus_Curiae_Brief.pdf|title = Case No. S147999 in the Supreme Court of the State of California, In re Marriage Cases Judicial Council Coordination Proceeding No. 4365(...) - APA California Amicus Brief — As Filed|access-date = 2010-12-21}}</ref> The Catholic Church still [[Catholic views on homosexuality|officially teaches]] that "homosexual tendencies" are "objectively disordered".<ref>{{cite news |title=Stances of Faiths on LGBTQ Issues: Roman Catholic Church |url=https://www.hrc.org/resources/stances-of-faiths-on-lgbt-issues-roman-catholic-church |access-date=26 August 2020 |work=HRC}}</ref> In 2016, anti-LGBT rhetoric was increasing in Indonesia under the Twitter hashtag #TolakLGBT (#RejectLGBT) and claims that LGBT is a disease.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mollman |first1=Steve |title="LGBT is a disease, not a human right"—a growing movement in Indonesia rejects gay rights |url=https://qz.com/617445/lgbt-is-a-disease-not-a-human-right-a-growing-movement-in-indonesia-rejects-gay-rights/ |access-date=25 August 2020 |work=Quartz |date=16 February 2016 |language=en}}</ref> In 2019, Archbishop [[Marek Jędraszewski]] claimed that a "rainbow plague" is threatening Poland.<ref>{{cite news |title=Liberals fear unrest as Poland Catholic Church doubles down on anti-gay rhetoric |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-poland-lgbt-bishop/liberals-fear-unrest-as-poland-catholic-church-doubles-down-on-anti-gay-rhetoric-idUSKCN1US1EN |access-date=20 August 2020 |work=Reuters |date=2 August 2019 |language=en}}</ref> In 2020, the education minister defended an official who warned that "LGBT virus" was threatening Polish schools, and was more dangerous than [[COVID-19]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tilles |first1=Daniel |title=Education minister defends official who warned "LGBT virus" threatens Polish schools |url=https://notesfrompoland.com/2020/08/25/education-minister-defends-official-who-warned-lgbt-virus-threatens-polish-schools/ |access-date=25 August 2020 |work=Notes From Poland |date=25 August 2020}}</ref>
===Homosexuality as ungodly=== {{anchor|Adam and Steve}}The phrase "God made [[Adam and Eve]], not Adam and Steve" is a slogan used as shorthand alluding to a Bible-based argument that homosexuality is sinful and unnatural.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Smith |first1=Ralph R. |last2=Windes |first2=Russel R. |title=Progay/Antigay: The Rhetorical War Over Sexuality |date=3 February 2000 |publisher=SAGE Publications |isbn=978-1-4522-6372-4 |page=63 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g_dyAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA63 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last = Clarke | first = Victoria | title = What about the children? arguments against lesbian and gay parenting | journal = [[Women's Studies International Forum]] | volume = 24 | issue = 5 | pages = 555–570 | doi = 10.1016/S0277-5395(01)00193-5 | date = September–October 2001 | url = http://eprints.uwe.ac.uk/21177/ }}</ref> A Christianity Today article in December 1970 reported on attitudes in San Francisco, quoting a graffiti that said, "If God had wanted homosexuals, he would have created Adam and Freddy."<ref name="CT-1970">{{cite journal |journal=Christianity Today |first=Robert L. |last=Cleath |title='Gays' Go Radical |url=https://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/1970/december-4/gays-go-radical.html |publisher=Christianity Today International |location=Carol Stream, Illinois |date=December 4, 1970 |issn=0009-5753 |pages=40–41 |access-date=26 August 2020}}</ref> In 1977 in Dade County, [[Anita Bryant]] made a similar comment, only her version was "Adam and Bruce".{{refn |name=CC-1977 |The Church and Homosexuals, Christian Century, 1 June 1977, p. 528; as quoted in Balch (2007) p. 22}}<ref name="Carroll-1990">{{cite book |last=Carroll |first=Peter N. |title=It Seemed Like Nothing Happened: America in the 1970s |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oPlNcHQUvSAC&pg=PA292-IA1 |year=1990 |publisher=Rutgers University Press |location=New Brunswick, New Jersey |isbn=978-0-8135-1538-0 |pages=292– |oclc=183352949 |orig-year=1st pub. 1990 |access-date=26 August 2020}}</ref> By 1979, Jerry Falwell had used "Adam and Steve".<ref name="CT-1979">Christianity Today, 16 November 1979, p.48, as quoted in {{cite book |last=Balch |first=David L. |title=Homosexuality, Science, and the "Plain Sense" of Scripture |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5RhKAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA22 |date=1 July 2007 |publisher=Wipf & Stock Publishers |isbn=978-1-55635-538-7 |page=22 |oclc=535493879 |access-date=26 August 2020}}</ref> In 1977, it was used on a protest sign, as mentioned in a ''New York Times'' news service report about a November 19 rally in Houston that year.<ref name="newsweek"/><ref>{{cite news |last=Klemesrud |first=Judy |author-link=Judy Lee Klemesrud |title=Equal Rights Plan and Abortion Are Opposed by 15,000 at Rally |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1977/11/20/archives/equal-rights-plan-and-abortion-are-opposed-by-15000-at-rally-like-a.html |work=New York Times |date=November 20, 1977 |access-date=2008-12-26 }}</ref> The phrase was used in "The Gay Bar", an episode of ''[[Maude (TV series)|Maude]]'' broadcast on December 3, 1977. Two years later, [[Jerry Falwell]] gave the phrase wider circulation in a ''[[Christianity Today]]'' report of a press conference he had given.<ref name="newsweek"/><ref>{{cite book | last = Balch | first = David | title = Homosexuality, science, and the "plain sense" of Scripture | publisher = Wm. B. Eerdmans | location = Grand Rapids, Mich | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-8028-4698-3 | page=22}}</ref> The phrase later acquired a certain notoriety, and, when used to name a pair of characters in a work of fiction, helps to identify them as members of a homosexual pair ([[Paul Rudnick]]'s play ''The Most Fabulous Story Ever Told'',<ref name="newsweek"/><ref>{{cite news | last = Hurwitt | first = Robert | title = Adam and Steve's adventures in paradise | work = San Francisco Chronicle | page = E4 | date = 21 May 2001 | url = http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Adam-and-Steve-s-adventures-in-paradise-2919586.php }}</ref> the 2005 film ''[[Adam & Steve]]'' and other works).<ref name="newsweek"/> The phrase was used by the [[Democratic Unionist Party]] MP [[David Simpson (Northern Ireland politician)|David Simpson]] during the 2013 British [[House of Commons (UK)|House of Commons]]' [[Marriage (Same-Sex Couples) Bill|debate on same-sex marriage]], although a slip of the tongue saying "in the Garden of Eden, it was Adam and Steve" initially caused laughter in the chamber.<ref>{{cite news | last = Hennessy | first = Mark | title = British MPs back gay marriage legislation | work = The Irish Times | url = http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2013/0206/1224329707241.html | date = 6 February 2013 }}</ref><ref name="newsweek">{{cite news |last1=Schonfeld |first1=Zach |title=The Surprising History of the Phrase 'Adam and Eve, Not Adam and Steve' |url=https://www.newsweek.com/surprising-history-phrase-adam-and-eve-not-adam-and-steve-348164 |access-date=21 August 2020 |work=Newsweek |date=1 July 2015 |language=en}}</ref> The phrase was eventually reclaimed by LGBT people and used in blogs, comics, and other media mocking the anti-gay message.<ref name="newsweek"/>
===Homosexuality as a lifestyle=== Closely related to the idea of "homosexual recruitment" is the idea of a "homosexual lifestyle" or "gay lifestyle", which LGBT people choose voluntarily rather than having a non-heterosexual [[sexual orientation]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Spitko |first1=E. Gary |title=Antigay Bias in Role-Model Occupations |year=2017 |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press |isbn=978-0-8122-4870-8 |page=89 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=itRzDQAAQBAJ&q=anti-gay+%22lifestyle%22&pg=PA89 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Mutz |first1=Larry |title=A Fairy Tale: The Myth of the Homosexual Lifestyle in Anti-Gay-and-Lesbian Rhetoric |journal=Women's Rights Law Reporter |date=2006 |volume=27 |pages=69– }}</ref> Christian right activists also may worry that increasing LGBT rights will make the "gay lifestyle" more attractive to young people.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Barton |first1=Bernadette |title=Pray the Gay Away: The Extraordinary Lives of Bible Belt Gays |date=October 2012 |publisher=NYU Press |isbn=978-0-8147-2442-2 |page=194 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vW9LEqpY0-sC&q=gay+%22lifestyle%22&pg=PA194 |language=en}}</ref>
=== Homosexual acts as sin === {{Main|Religion and homosexuality}} [[File:Anti gay San Francisco.jpg|thumb|Religious protest of homosexuality in San Francisco]] [[File:God hates lechery.jpg|thumb|Sign in Tel Aviv: "God hates lechery"]] Many conservative Christians consider homosexual acts to be inherently sinful based on scriptural passages such as [[Leviticus 18:22]] ("You shall not lie with a male as with a woman; it is an abomination"), [[Leviticus 20:13]] ("If a man lies with a male as with a woman, both of them have committed an abomination; they shall be put to death, their blood is upon them"), and [[1 Corinthians 6]]:9–10 ("Do you not know that wrongdoers will not inherit the kingdom of God? Do not be deceived! Fornicators, idolaters, adulterers, male prostitutes, sodomites, thieves, the greedy, drunkards, revilers, robbers—none of these will inherit the kingdom of God.")<ref name="Gnuse" /> The story of [[Sodom and Gomorrah]], a city that was burned down due to the sins of its inhabitants, is sometimes portrayed as divine retribution for homosexual behavior.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Pitt |first1=Richard N. |title="Killing the Messenger": Religious Black Gay Men's Neutralization of Anti-Gay Religious Messages |journal=Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion |date=2010 |volume=49 |issue=1 |pages=56–72 |doi=10.1111/j.1468-5906.2009.01492.x}}</ref><ref name=Gnuse>{{cite journal |last1=Gnuse |first1=Robert K. |title=Seven Gay Texts: Biblical Passages Used to Condemn Homosexuality |journal=Biblical Theology Bulletin: Journal of Bible and Culture |date=2015 |volume=45 |issue=2 |pages=68–87 |doi=10.1177/0146107915577097|s2cid=170127256 }}</ref>
Various inflammatory and controversial slogans, including some listed in the next section, have been used by opponent congregations and individuals, particularly by [[Fred Phelps]], founder of the [[Westboro Baptist Church]]. These slogans have included "God Hates Fags", "Fear God Not Fags", and "[[Matthew Shepard]] Burns In Hell".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://portlandmercury.com/2000-09-14/city.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050310064914/http://portlandmercury.com/2000-09-14/city.html |archive-date=2005-03-10 |title=Dunn, Katia. "What If God Were Gay?". Portland Mercury |access-date=2014-03-12}}</ref>
Homosexuality is also frequently considered sinful in [[Islam]]. In some Middle Eastern countries, acts of homosexuality are punishable by death. Anti-LGBT rhetoric and political homophobia is growing in some Muslim countries.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Boellstorff |first1=Tom |title=The emergence of political homophobia in Indonesia: masculinity and national belonging |journal=Ethnos |date=2004 |volume=69 |issue=4 |pages=465–486 |doi=10.1080/0014184042000302308|s2cid=143971007 |url=http://www.escholarship.org/uc/item/3k89m64b }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hamdi |first1=Nassim |last2=Lachheb |first2=Monia |last3=Anderson |first3=Eric |title=Masculinity, homosexuality and sport in an Islamic state of increasing homohysteria |journal=Journal of Gender Studies |date=2017 |volume=26 |issue=6 |pages=688–701 |doi=10.1080/09589236.2016.1155979|s2cid=147347384 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Weiss |first1=Meredith L. |last2=Bosia |first2=Michael J. |editor1-last=Korycki |editor1-first=Katarzyna |editor2-last=Nasirzadeh |editor2-first=Abouzar |title=Global Homophobia: States, Movements, and the Politics of Oppression |publisher=University of Illinois Press |isbn=978-0-252-09500-9 |chapter-url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/303759230 |chapter=Homophobia as a Tool of Statecraft: Iran and Its Queers|date=31 August 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Thoreson |first1=Ryan Richard |title=Troubling the waters of a 'wave of homophobia': Political economies of anti-queer animus in sub-Saharan Africa |journal=Sexualities |date=2014 |volume=17 |issue=1–2 |pages=23–42 |doi=10.1177/1363460713511098|s2cid=144030716 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Wieringa |first1=Saskia E. |editor1-last=Fealy |editor1-first=Greg |editor2-last=Ricci |editor2-first=Ronit |title=Contentious Belonging: Contentious Belonging |publisher=ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute |isbn=978-981-4843-49-2 |language=en |chapter=Is the Recent Wave of Homophobia in Indonesia Unexpected?|date=27 May 2019 }}</ref>
Other religious leaders including Christians, Muslims, and Jews have denounced anti-LGBT rhetoric.<ref>{{cite news |title=Poland's Jewish leaders deplore stigmatization of LGBTQ people |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/poland-s-jewish-leaders-deplore-stigmatization-lgbt-people-n1231282 |access-date=24 August 2020 |work=NBC News |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=The Faith Leaders Leading the Fight for LGBTQ Equality |url=https://www.hrc.org/news/the-faith-leaders-leading-the-fight-for-lgbtq-equality |website=HRC |access-date=24 August 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Jones |first1=Ian |last2=Thorpe |first2=Kirsty |last3=Wootton |first3=Janet |title=Women and Ordination in the Christian Churches: International Perspectives |date=3 November 2011 |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing |isbn=978-0-567-23910-5 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rKPsUkiaj_4C&pg=PT357 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Santos |first1=A. |title=Social Movements and Sexual Citizenship in Southern Europe |date=28 November 2012 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-1-137-29640-5 |page=201 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vMA7_9icqQwC&pg=PT201 |language=en}}</ref>
===As Western ill===
Homosexuality is sometimes claimed to be non-existent in some non-Western countries, or to be an evil influence imported from the West.
Prime Minister [[Mahathir Mohamad]] of Malayasia employed anti-gay rhetoric as part of his "Asian values" program, describing homosexuality as one of several Western ills.<ref name="Shah-2017">{{cite book |last=Shah |first=Shanon |title=The Making of a Gay Muslim: Religion, Sexuality and Identity in Malaysia and Britain |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wn86DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA130 |access-date=26 August 2020 |series=Palgrave Studies in Lived Religion and Societal Challenges. |date=17 October 2017 |publisher=Springer International Publishing |location=Cham, Switzerland |isbn=978-3-319-63130-1 |page=130 |oclc=1027079609}}</ref> Mohamad used it for political advantage in the 1998 scandal involving the sacking and jailing of MP and former [[Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia|Deputy Prime Minister]] [[Anwar Ibrahim]] by Mohamad amidst accusations of sodomy that the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' termed a "blatantly political fix-up".<ref>{{Cite news |first=Peter |last=Hartcher |title=Outdated political thuggery embarrasses Malaysia |url=https://www.smh.com.au/opinion/politics/outdated-political-thuggery-embarrasses-malaysia-20100222-ornl.html |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=23 February 2010 |access-date=26 August 2020}}</ref> Anwar was subsequently subjected to two trials and sentenced to nine years imprisonment for corruption and sodomy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www7.nationalacademies.org/humanrights/Cases/CHR_068423.htm |title=Anwar Ibrahim |date=6 June 2014 |access-date=10 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213034949/http://www7.nationalacademies.org/humanrights/Cases/CHR_068423.htm |archive-date=13 February 2015 |url-status=dead}}</ref>
While in New York for a meeting of the United Nations, Iranian President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] was invited to speak at Columbia University in New York to give a lecture. When responding to a student question afterward, he said, speaking through an interpreter: "In Iran, we don't have homosexuals like in your country."<ref>{{cite news |last=Goldman |first=Russell |title=Ahmadinejad: No Gays, No Oppression of Women in Iran |url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/story?id=3642673 |date=September 24, 2007 |work=[[ABC News]] |access-date=26 August 2020 }}</ref> In his native [[Farsi language|Farsi]], he used the slang equivalent of ''faggot'', not the neutral term for a "homosexual".<ref name="Martel-2019">{{cite book |last1=Martel |first1=Frédéric |last2=Bronski |first2=Michael |title=Global Gay: How Gay Culture is Changing the World |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8r34DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA203 |date=9 April 2019 |publisher=MIT Press |location=Cambridge, Mass. |isbn=978-0-262-53705-6 |pages=203– |chapter=8. "In Iran, There Are No Homosexuals" |oclc=1001431180 |translator-last=Baudoin |translator-first=Patsy |orig-year=1st pub. [[Flammarian]], Paris 2013<!-- Global gay : comment la révolution gay change le monde--> |access-date=26 August 2020 |quote=The former President of Iran evaded an American student's question on the execution of homosexuals by saying, 'In Iran, we don't have homosexuals like in your country. This does not exist in our country. In Iran we do not have this phenomenon. I do not know who told you that we have.' (Note that in this speech, Ahmadinejad used the Farsi term ''hamjensbaz'', 'faggot', not the more neutral term ''hamjensgara'', 'homosexual'.{{thin space}})}}</ref>
Other countries and regions viewing homosexuality as a Western disease include Vietnam,<ref>{{cite web |last=Lam |first=Charles |title=UCI Anthropologist Out To Prove Gay People Exist ... In Vietnam |url=https://www.ocweekly.com/uci-anthropologist-out-to-prove-gay-people-exist-in-vietnam-6464912/ |date=28 October 2013 |website=OC Weekly |access-date=31 August 2020 }}</ref> China,<ref>{{cite newspaper |newspaper=Bay Area Reporter |last=Huang |first=Wen |title=Gayness as a Western disease |url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/?a=d&d=BAR20010104.1.35&e=-------en--20--1--txt-txIN--------1 |date=4 January 2001 |volume=31 |issue=1 |publisher=Center for Bibliographical Studies and Research |access-date=31 August 2020 }}</ref> Ethiopia,<ref>{{cite web |last=Baker |first=Katie J. ===Conflation with child abuse=== [[File:Stop Pedofilii, Warsaw, 2.jpg|thumb|"Stop Pedofilii" van belonging to {{ill|Fundacja Pro|pl}}, falsely claiming that pedophilia is advocated by the "LGBT lobby"]] [[Societal attitudes toward homosexuality#Association with child abuse and pedophilia|The claim that homosexuals sexually abuse children]] predates the current era, as it was leveled against [[pederasty|pederasts]] even during [[Classical antiquity|antiquity]].<ref>[[Lucian]]. ''Erotes''</ref> Lawmakers and social commentators have sometimes expressed a concern that normalizing homosexuality would also lead to normalizing pedophilia, if it were determined that pedophilia too were a sexual orientation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wral.com/stam-calls-pedophilia-bestiality-sexual-orientations-/13762098/|title=Stam calls pedophilia, sadism 'sexual orientations'|author=Stam, Paul|date=25 June 2014|publisher=WRAL}}</ref> A related claim is that [[LGBT adoption]] is done for the purpose of grooming children for sexual exploitation.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wądołowska |first1=Agnieszka |title=Activist who said "gay couples adopt kids to rape them" will not face trial after Polish court rejects case |url=https://notesfrompoland.com/2020/05/29/activist-who-said-gay-couples-adopt-kids-to-rape-them-will-not-face-trial-after-polish-court-rejects-case/ |access-date=26 August 2020 |work=Notes From Poland |date=29 May 2020}}</ref> Others have falsely claimed that the "+" in "LGBT+" refers to "pedophiles, zoophiles, necrophiles".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Santora |first1=Marc |title=Poland's Populists Pick a New Top Enemy: Gay People |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/07/world/europe/poland-gay-rights.html |access-date=26 August 2020 |work=The New York Times |date=7 April 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=What does the plus in 'LGBT+' mean? |url=https://www.statepress.com/article/2018/10/spartcult-what-is-the-plus-in-lgbt-plus |access-date=26 August 2020 |work=The Arizona State Press}}</ref> In 2020, online conspiracy theorists alleged that LGBT is adding a P for "pedosexual" and that pedophiles have created the LGBT identities of "clovergender" and "agefluid". All of these claims have been rated false by fact checkers.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Link |first1=Devon |title=Fact check: 'Clovergender' isn't part of the LGBTQ community |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2020/07/30/fact-check-clovergender-not-lgbtq-gender-sexual-identity/5504085002/ |access-date=26 August 2020 |work=USA TODAY |date=30 July 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Caldera |first1=Camille |title=Fact check: LGBTQ community rejects false association with pedophiles |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2020/07/30/fact-check-lgbtq-community-rejects-false-association-pedophiles/5462805002/ |access-date=26 August 2020 |work=USA TODAY |date=30 July 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Evon |first1=David |title=Are Pedophiles Claiming to be 'Age Fluid'? |url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/pedophiles-age-fluid/ |access-date=26 August 2020 |work=Snopes.com |date=27 July 2020}}</ref>
The empirical research shows that sexual orientation does not affect the likelihood that people will abuse children.<ref name=herekmolest>[[Gregory M. Herek]]:[http://psychology.ucdavis.edu/rainbow/html/facts_molestation.html Facts About Homosexuality and Child Molestation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100419022239/http://psychology.ucdavis.edu/rainbow/HTML/facts_molestation.html |date=19 April 2010 }}</ref><ref name=lamb>[[Michael Lamb (psychologist)|Michael Lamb]], [http://www.glad.org/uploads/docs/cases/gill-v-office-of-personnel-management/2009-11-17-doma-aff-lamb.pdf Affidavit – United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts (2009)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225193923/http://www.glad.org/uploads/docs/cases/gill-v-office-of-personnel-management/2009-11-17-doma-aff-lamb.pdf |date=25 December 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.apa.org/helpcenter/sexual-orientation.aspx |title=Sexual orientation, homosexuality, and bisexuality |publisher=American Psychological Association |access-date=2010-11-30 }}</ref>
=== Recruitment === <!-- [[File:Save Our Children From Homosexuality Brochure.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|Brochure used by [[Save Our Children]] to repeal Dade County, Florida [[Dade County ordinance 77-4|ordinance 77-4]] ]] --> The charge of "homosexual recruitment" is an argument used by social conservatives which alleges that LGBT people engage in concerted efforts to indoctrinate children into homosexuality. ===LGBT conspiracy=== [[File:Praha, Na Příkopě, Pride 2017, Homo Lobby.jpg|thumb|upright|Marchers at Prague Pride 2017 carry sign satirizing "Homo Lobby"]]
====Homintern==== In 1937 the English gay classics scholar Sir [[Maurice Bowra]] referred to himself as part of the "Homintern".<ref>"Bowra, Sir (Cecil) Maurice (1898–1971)" by L. G. Mitchell, [http://www.oxforddnb.com "Oxford Dictionary of National Biography"]</ref> However, there are competing claims about who coined the term – including [[Jocelyn Brooke]], [[Harold Norse]] and [[W. H. Auden]]. A takeoff on [[Comintern]] (Communist International), it was meant to convey the idea of a global homosexual community.{{efn|name="Powell-1981"}}{{efn|"The word 'Homintern', which I coined in 1939, is attributed to [[W. H. Auden|Auden]], who used it in an article in the [[Partisan Review]] about 1941, and has passed into the language. A takeoff on [[Comintern]] (Communist International), it was meant to convey the idea of a global homosexual community." –[[Harold Norse]] (1989; correction: Auden's first articles in ''Partisan Review'' was in 1950)<ref name="nose">Harold Norse: ''Memoirs of a Bastard Angel'', W. Morrow, 1989, {{ISBN|9780688067045}}, p. 77</ref>}}{{efn|"[[Anthony Powell]] suggested that his friend [[Jocelyn Brooke]] invented the term that Harold Nurse tells us Auden stole from him. Whoever invented it provided us with a splendid word to explain the social and cultural power of homosexuality." –Patrick Higgins (1993)<ref name=higgins>''A Queer Reader'', ed. Patrick Higgins, Fourth Estate (UK), 1993, p. 315</ref>}}
Auden used the term in the ''[[Partisan Review]]'' in 1950, entitling his review of a book on Oscar Wilde: ''"A Playboy of the Western World: St. Oscar, the Homintern Martyr."''<ref>{{cite magazine |last= Auden |first= W. H. |date= April 1950 |volume= 17 |issue= 4 |page= 391-2 |title= A Playboy of the Western World: St. Oscar, The Homintern Martyr |magazine= Partisan Review |location= New York |url= http://archives.bu.edu/collections/partisan-review/search/detail?id=284002 |access-date= 29 September 2020}}</ref>
"Homintern" was also used by American Senator [[Joe McCarthy]] during the [[McCarthyist]] scare in the 1950s, who used it to claim that the administrations of [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] and [[Harry S. Truman]] were set on destroying America from within.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Blumenthal|first1=Max|title=Republican Gomorrah: Inside the Movement that Shattered the Party|date=13 July 2010|publisher=Nation Books|isbn=9781568584171|page=205|edition=reprint|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Oa-TsVnbYUIC&pg=PA205|access-date=9 March 2015}}</ref> Attempts were made to link [[Communism]] and homosexuality, with "homintern" a play on the word "[[Comintern]]" (the short name of the Communist International). But the word was also used ironically by those in favor of gay rights.<ref name=RVOURTA0G/><ref name=spectator>[https://www.spectator.co.uk/2016/04/from-auden-to-wilde-a-roll-call-of-gay-talent/ "From Auden to Wilde: a roll call of gay talent"]</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Woods |first1=Gregory |title=Homintern: How Gay Culture Liberated the Modern World |date=2017 |publisher=Yale University Press |isbn=978-0-300-22874-8 |language=en}}</ref>
''Homintern'' also appeared in a number of mass-circulation magazine articles during the 1960s - such as ''[[Ramparts (magazine)|Ramparts]]'', which in 1966 published an article by [[Gene Marine]] about the Homintern. It was also frequently used in the [[American conservatism|conservative]] magazine ''[[National Review]]''. [[William F. Buckley, Jr.]] would warn of the machinations of the Homintern on his TV talk show ''[[Firing Line (TV series)|Firing Line]]'' – feeding the conservative belief that the Homintern deliberately manipulated culture to encourage homosexuality by promoting [[camp (style)|camp]] programs such as the popular 1960s TV series ''[[Batman (TV series)|Batman]]''. Such magazine articles were often illustrated with the color lavender and the Homintern was sometimes called "the lavender conspiracy". It was subsequently claimed that there was a secret worldwide network of gay [[art gallery]] owners, ballet directors, [[movie producer]]s, record label executives and photographers who, behind the scenes, determined who would become successful artists, dancers, actors, and models.<ref name=RVOURTA0G>{{cite news | title= A review of "Gay Artists in Modern American Culture An Imagined Conspiracy" by Michael S. Sherry | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/11/25/RVOURTA0G.DTL&type=printable | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | date=25 November 2007 | access-date=23 January 2008}}</ref>
The historian [[Michael S. Sherry]] has used the term ''hominterm discourse'' "for the untidy bundle of ideas and accusations about the gay creative presence".<ref name=mss>{{cite book | last=Sherry | first=Michael S. | title=Gay Artists in Modern American Culture: An Imagined Conspiracy | location=Chapel Hill | publisher=University of North Carolina Press | year=2007 | isbn=978-0-8078-3121-2 | url=https://archive.org/details/gayartistsinmode00sher }}</ref>
====Gaystapo==== The term "Gaystapo" ({{lang-fr|link=no|Gestapette}}) was coined in France in the 1940s by political satirist [[Jean Galtier-Boissière]] for the [[Vichy France|Vichy]] education minister, [[Abel Bonnard]]. It was subsequently applied by [[National Front (France)|National Front]] leader [[Jean-Marie Le Pen]] to [[Florian Philippot]], who he accused of being a bad influence on [[Marine Le Pen]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Perreau |first1=Bruno |title=Queer Theory: The French Response |date=2016 |publisher=Stanford University Press |isbn=978-1-5036-0046-1 |url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Queer_Theory/p9K1DQAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=Gaystapo&pg=PA118&printsec=frontcover |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Tin |first1=Louis-Georges |title=The Dictionary of Homophobia: A Global History of Gay & Lesbian Experience |date=2008 |publisher=Arsenal |isbn=978-1-55152-314-9 |url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Dictionary_of_Homophobia/aK02DwAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=Gaystapo&pg=PT224&printsec=frontcover |language=en}}</ref>
====Homosexual and Gay mafia==== The English critic [[Kenneth Tynan]] wrote to A.C. Spectorsky (editor of ''[[Playboy]]'') in 1967 proposing an article on the "Homosexual Mafia" in the arts.<ref>Kenneth Tynan Letters (Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1994)</ref> Spectorsky declined, although he admitted that "culture hounds were paying homage to faggotismo as they have never done before" ''Playboy'' would subsequently run a panel on gay issues in April 1971.
"Gay Mafia" became more widely used in the US media in the 1980s and 1990s, such as the American daily The ''[[New York Post]]''. The term was also used by the British [[Tabloid journalism|tabloid]] ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' in 1998 in response to what it claimed was sinister dominance by gay men in the [[First Blair ministry|Labour Party Cabinet]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/sun-rejects-outing-and-sacks-parris-sacks-parris-and-rejects-outing-1184294.html|title='Sun' rejects outing and sacks Parris sacks Parris and rejects outing|work=The Independent|access-date=29 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/212737.stm|title=BBC News – UK – Sun changes mind over gays|publisher=News.bbc.co.uk|access-date=29 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200910/cmhansrd/cm100407/halltext/100407h0001.htm|title=House of Commons Hansard Debates for 07 Apr 2010 (pt 0001)|publisher=Publications.parliament.uk|access-date=29 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/11/news/11iht-brit.t_2.html|title=A 'Gay Mafia' in Whitehall? === Misgendering === {{Further info|Misgendering}}{{See also|Deadnaming}}
Misgendering is the act of labelling others with a gender that does not match their gender identity.<ref name="Serano2009">{{cite book|author=Julia Serano|title=Whipping Girl: A Transsexual Woman on Sexism and the Scapegoating of Femininity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fR5ji5h5g1MC|date=20 May 2009|publisher=Seal Press|isbn=978-0-7867-4791-7}}</ref> Misgendering can be deliberate or accidental. It ordinarily takes the form of a person using pronouns to describe someone that are not the ones they use,{{citation needed |reason=Original url imported from [[Transphobia]] triggered SPS edit filter for AuthorHouse ('Transgender Explained For Those Who Are Not'; Herman; 2009) |date=August 2020}}<ref name=":24">{{Cite book|title = Transgender Employment Experiences: Gendered Perceptions and the Law|last = Bender-Baird|first = Kyla|publisher = SUNY Press|year = 2011|isbn = 978-1438436746|pages = 5–24}}</ref> calling a person "ma'am" or "sir" in contradiction to the person's gender identity,<ref>{{Cite book|title = Looking Queer: Body Image and Identity in Lesbian, Bisexual, Gay, and Transgender Communities (Haworth Gay & Lesbian Studies)|last = DeCecco|first = John|publisher = Routledge|year = 2012|isbn = 978-0789004635|location = New Jersey}}</ref> using a pre-transition name for someone instead of a post-transition one,<ref name=":24" /> called "[[deadnaming]]".<ref>{{cite news |first=Meredith Ramirez |last=Talusan |title=What 'deadnaming' means, and why you shouldn't do it to Caitlyn Jenner |work=Fusion |date=June 4, 2015 |url=http://fusion.net/story/144324/what-deadnaming-means-and-why-you-shouldnt-do-it-to-caitlyn-jenner/ |access-date=2015-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Fae|first1=Jane|title=Changing your name should be a joyous moment, but for many it's a nightmare|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/may/19/changing-your-name-nightmare-trans|website=Comment is Free|access-date=8 July 2015|date=19 May 2015}}</ref>
=== Deception and masquerade ===
Some transphobic slurs such as ''[[shemale]], trap,'' and ''ladyboy'' capitalize on the idea that [[Trans woman|trans women]] are men masquerading as women. The concept of a person identifying to a gender that does not correspond with their physical sex identity has often been twisted into jokes about how repulsive such a person must be.<ref>{{Cite web|title = How I Learned to Hate Transgender People|url = http://magazine.good.is/articles/how-i-learned-to-hate-transgender-people|access-date = 2015-05-05|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150505055005/http://magazine.good.is/articles/how-i-learned-to-hate-transgender-people|archive-date = 2015-05-05|url-status = dead}}</ref>

=== In feminism ===
Some positions within feminist theory have used denialist rhetoric viewed as transphobic.
In 1979, American radical feminist Janice Raymond published ''[[The Transsexual Empire: The Making of the She-Male]]''. In it, she wrote that, "All transsexuals rape women's bodies by reducing the real female form to an artifact, appropriating this body for themselves."<ref name=Raymond-1979>{{cite book |last=Raymond |first=Janice G. |title=The transsexual empire |publisher=Beacon Press |location=Boston, Massachusetts |year=1979 |isbn=9780807021644 }}</ref>{{page needed |date=August 2020}} A common position in radical feminism maintain that trans women are not women in a literal sense and should not be in women-only spaces.<ref name="Goldberg">{{cite magazine |last1=Goldberg |first1=Michelle |author-link=Michelle Goldberg |title=What Is a Woman? |magazine=[[The New Yorker]] |date=August 4, 2014 |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/08/04/woman-2 |issn=0028-792X |oclc=320541675 |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] |access-date=November 20, 2015}}</ref>
Some [[Second-wave feminism|second-wave feminists]] perceive trans men and women respectively as "traitors" and "infiltrators" to womanhood.<ref name="Erickson-Schroth 2014">{{cite book |last1=Erickson-Schroth |first1=Laura |title=Trans Bodies, Trans Selves: A Resource for the Transgender Community |date=2014-05-12 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn=978-0199325351 |pages=568–569 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7Ef1AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA568|quote=Some feminists have perceived transmasculine people as traitors—that is, as women who identify politically with men. When inclusive of trans men, these feminists have often gendered them as women. Conversely, these feminists have tended to perceive transfeminine people as infiltrators of womanhood and of women's space.}}</ref> In a 1997 article British lesbian feminist [[Sheila Jeffreys]] wrote that {{nobr|"[T]ranssexualism}} should be seen as a violation of human rights." Jeffreys also argued that by [[Transition (transgender)|transitioning]] medically and socially, trans women are "constructing a conservative fantasy of what women should be. They are inventing an essence of womanhood which is deeply insulting and restrictive."<ref name="Jeffreys-1997">{{Cite journal |journal=Journal of Lesbian Studies |last=Jeffreys |first=Sheila |title=Transgender activism: a lesbian feminist perspective |volume=1 |issue=3–4 |pages=55–74 |doi=10.1300/J155v01n03_03 |date=May 1997 }} [http://www.rapereliefshelter.bc.ca/sites/default/files/imce/Transgender%20Activism%20A%20Lesbian%20Feminist%20Perspective%20by%20Sheila%20Jeffreys%2C%20Journal%20of%20Lesbian%20Studies%201997%5B1%5D.pdf Pdf.]</ref>
==Effects== According to one study, "homophobic epithets foster dehumanization and avoidance of gay people, in ways that other insults or labels do not."<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fasoli |first1=Fabio |last2=Paladino |first2=Maria Paola |last3=Carnaghi |first3=Andrea |last4=Jetten |first4=Jolanda |last5=Bastian |first5=Brock |last6=Bain |first6=Paul G. |title=Not "just words": Exposure to homophobic epithets leads to dehumanizing and physical distancing from gay men: Homophobic epithets and dehumanization |journal=European Journal of Social Psychology |date=2016 |volume=46 |issue=2 |pages=237–248 |doi=10.1002/ejsp.2148|url=https://eprints.qut.edu.au/90602/11/EJSP_dehumanization_uncorrected.pdf }}</ref> Another study found that homophobia "results in substantial health and welfare effects".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Plummer |first1=David |title=Homophobia and health: Unjust, anti-social, harmful and endemic |journal=Health Care Analysis |date=1995 |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=150–156 |doi=10.1007/BF02198224|pmid=10143359 |s2cid=34638623 }}</ref> ==Legality and censorship== [[Hate speech]] against LGBT people, or incitement to hatred against them, is criminalized in some countries.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hate crime & hate speech |url=https://www.ilga-europe.org/what-we-do/our-advocacy-work/hate-crime-hate-speech |website=[[ILGA-Europe]] |access-date=22 August 2020}}</ref>
